bibl.title: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie B. Lawrence, May 17, 1875

div1.p: Reed writes that he made a medical call on Emilie Lawrence's relative, Mrs. Vaughan, on his way home to New York. He had been in North Carolina visiting Emilie Lawrence.

div1.head: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie B. Lawrence, May 17, 1875
div1.p:
I wrote you
a short note from Boykins, this
morning, and already I am en-
aged in writing a second one
from this town. Do not think that
I do this simply to show you that
I am faithful to my vows; but
rather would I have you know
that it is because of the sin-
cere love that I bear you- I
cannot avoid writing whenever
an opportunity presents it-
self- It makes me feel nearer
to you; & to be near you, if not
in body, yet in heart, is my fon-
dest & dearest wish.
It is now 10.15 P.M- I have just
returned from a visit to Mr
Vaughan & your sister- Remained
about an hour & had a very
pleasant conversation- Mrs. V.
was not able to leave her bed
owing to a slight inflammation
of her tonsils, but you know such
things are not very alarming to
an old physician, so that I did
not hesitate to sit down by her
bedside & feel her pulse after the
most modern professional style.
She is certainly a very sweet
lady & has the sweetest expres-
sion of the face of any lady
I ever saw, with only one ex-
ception & that is yourself. Now
pray don't toss your head about
& exclaim, “Dr Reed, you ought
not to say that,” for I do say
it in the face of the whole world.
And who has a greater right to
thus speak than myself, since
you are the dearest one to me of
any mortal on this round globe?

You don't know me yet, but
one of these days (and may an-
gels hasten the time) you will
know me; then will your doubts
fade away like mists before
the morning sun and reveal
to you a heart having but one
purpose, & that purpose, your
happiness- I could continue on
in this strain to the end of my
letter, but for your sake I will
repress my feelings.

I leave here, tomor-
row morning, at 7 oclock, for Not-
toway Co.- I shall first visit my
sister & then return to Churchland,
Jimmie's home, early in June. It
was too bad that I missed the
train, this morning & was thus com-
pelled to disappoint my brother
twice in succession- Still it
cannot be expected that a youth
who has labored so hard as I
have during the past week,
should be able to manage a
Railroad, at the same time. Lest
you may misunderstand the first
part of the last sentence, I will
explain by saying that the labor was
sweet & the laborer most willing.

Trusting that I may be
with you in my dreams, I bid
you an affectionate good-night-
div1.closer:
As ever,
Devotedly yours, Walter.
P.S. will write you on Wednesday,
Walter.
